sn41.2:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā therā bhikkhū macchikāsaṇḍe viharanti ambāṭakavane.
sn41.2:1.1.eng: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.

sn41.2:1.2.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati there bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn41.2:1.2.eng: Then Citta the householder went up to them, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to them,

sn41.2:1.3.eng: “Honorable Seniors, please accept my offering of tomorrow’s meal.”

sn41.2:1.5.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn41.2:1.5.eng: Knowing that the senior mendicants had consented, Citta got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled them, keeping them on his right, before leaving.

sn41.2:1.6.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena cittassa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdiṃsu.
sn41.2:1.6.eng: Then when the night had passed, the senior mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, went to Citta’s home, and sat down on the seats spread out.

sn41.2:2.1.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati āyasmantaṃ theraṃ etadavoca:
sn41.2:2.1.eng: Then Citta went up to them, bowed, sat down to one side, and asked the senior venerable,

sn41.2:2.2.eng: “Honorable Senior, they speak of ‘the diversity of elements’.

sn41.2:2.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, dhātunānattaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā”ti?
sn41.2:2.3.eng: In what way did the Buddha speak of the diversity of elements?”

sn41.2:2.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā thero tuṇhī ahosi.
sn41.2:2.4.eng: When he said this, the venerable senior kept silent.

sn41.2:2.5.pli: Dutiyampi kho citto gahapati āyasmantaṃ theraṃ etadavoca:

sn41.2:2.7.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, dhātunānattaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā”ti?

sn41.2:2.8.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā thero tuṇhī ahosi.

sn41.2:2.9.pli: Tatiyampi kho citto gahapati āyasmantaṃ theraṃ etadavoca:
sn41.2:2.9.eng: And for a third time, Citta asked him,

sn41.2:2.10.eng: “Honorable Senior, they speak of ‘the diversity of elements’.

sn41.2:2.11.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, dhātunānattaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā”ti?
sn41.2:2.11.eng: In what way did the Buddha speak of the diversity of elements?”

sn41.2:2.12.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā thero tuṇhī ahosi.
sn41.2:2.12.eng: And a second time and a third time the senior venerable kept silent.

sn41.2:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā isidatto tasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe sabbanavako hoti.
sn41.2:3.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Isidatta was the most junior mendicant in that Saṅgha.

sn41.2:3.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā isidatto āyasmantaṃ theraṃ etadavoca:
sn41.2:3.2.eng: He said to the senior venerable,

sn41.2:3.3.pli: “byākaromahaṃ, bhante thera, cittassa gahapatino etaṃ pañhan”ti?
sn41.2:3.3.eng: “Honorable Senior, may I answer Citta’s question?”

sn41.2:3.4.pli: “Byākarohi tvaṃ, āvuso isidatta, cittassa gahapatino etaṃ pañhan”ti.

sn41.2:3.7.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, dhātunānattaṃ, vuttaṃ bhagavatā’”ti?
sn41.2:3.7.eng: In what way did the Buddha speak of the diversity of elements?’”

sn41.2:3.9.eng: “This is the diversity of elements spoken of by the Buddha.

sn41.2:3.10.eng: The eye element, the sights element, the eye consciousness element …

sn41.2:3.11.eng: The mind element, the idea element, the mind consciousness element.

sn41.2:3.12.pli: Ettāvatā kho, gahapati, dhātunānattaṃ vuttaṃ bhagavatā”ti.
sn41.2:3.12.eng: This is how the Buddha spoke of the diversity of elements.”

sn41.2:4.1.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati āyasmato isidattassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā there bhikkhū paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
sn41.2:4.1.eng: Then Citta, having approved and agreed with what Isidatta said, served and satisfied the senior mendicants with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

sn41.2:4.2.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū bhuttāvino onītapattapāṇino uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃsu.
sn41.2:4.2.eng: When the senior mendicants had eaten and washed their hands and bowls, they got up from their seats and left.

sn41.2:4.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā thero āyasmantaṃ isidattaṃ etadavoca:
sn41.2:4.3.eng: Then the senior venerable said to Venerable Isidatta,

sn41.2:4.4.pli: “sādhu kho taṃ, āvuso isidatta, eso pañho paṭibhāsi, neso pañho maṃ paṭibhāsi.
sn41.2:4.4.eng: “Isidatta, it’s good that you felt inspired to answer that question, because I didn’t.

sn41.2:4.5.pli: Tenahāvuso isidatta, yadā aññathāpi evarūpo pañho āgaccheyya, taññevettha paṭibhāseyyā”ti.
sn41.2:4.5.eng: So when a similar question comes up, you should also answer it as you feel inspired.”

sn41.3:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā therā bhikkhū macchikāsaṇḍe viharanti ambāṭakavane.
sn41.3:1.1.eng: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.

sn41.3:1.2.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati there bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn41.3:1.2.eng: Then Citta the householder went up to them, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to them,

sn41.3:1.3.eng: “Honorable Seniors, please accept my offering of tomorrow’s meal.”

sn41.3:1.5.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn41.3:1.5.eng: Then, knowing that the senior mendicants had consented, Citta got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled them, keeping them on his right, before leaving.

sn41.3:1.6.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena cittassa gahapatissa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdiṃsu.
sn41.3:1.6.eng: Then when the night had passed, the senior mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, went to Citta’s home, and sat down on the seats spread out.

sn41.3:2.1.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati āyasmantaṃ theraṃ etadavoca:
sn41.3:2.1.eng: So he went up to them, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the senior venerable:

sn41.3:2.2.pli: “yā imā, bhante thera, anekavihitā diṭṭhiyo loke uppajjanti:
sn41.3:2.2.eng: “Honorable Senior, there are many different views that arise in the world. For example:

sn41.3:2.3.pli: ‘sassato lokoti vā, asassato lokoti vā, antavā lokoti vā, anantavā lokoti vā, taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti vā, aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā.
sn41.3:2.3.eng: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are one and the same, or the soul is one thing, the body another; after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.

sn41.3:2.4.pli: Yāni cimāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni brahmajāle bhaṇitāni;
sn41.3:2.4.eng: And also the sixty-two misconceptions spoken of in “The Divine Net”.

sn41.3:2.5.pli: imā nu kho, bhante, diṭṭhiyo kismiṃ sati honti, kismiṃ asati na hontī”ti?
sn41.3:2.5.eng: When what exists do these views come to be? When what doesn’t exist do these views not come to be?”

sn41.3:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā thero tuṇhī ahosi.
sn41.3:3.1.eng: When he said this, the venerable senior kept silent.

sn41.3:3.3.pli: tatiyampi kho citto gahapati āyasmantaṃ theraṃ etadavoca:
sn41.3:3.3.eng: And for a third time, Citta said to him:

sn41.3:3.4.pli: “yā imā, bhante thera, anekavihitā diṭṭhiyo loke uppajjanti—
sn41.3:3.4.eng: “Honorable Senior, there are many different views that arise in the world. …

sn41.3:3.5.pli: sassato lokoti vā, asassato lokoti vā, antavā lokoti vā, anantavā lokoti vā, taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti vā, aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā.

sn41.3:3.6.pli: Yāni cimāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni brahmajāle bhaṇitāni;

sn41.3:3.7.pli: imā nu kho, bhante, diṭṭhiyo kismiṃ sati honti, kismiṃ asati na hontī”ti?
sn41.3:3.7.eng: When what exists do these views come to be? When what doesn’t exist do these views not come to be?”

sn41.3:3.8.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā thero tuṇhī ahosi.
sn41.3:3.8.eng: And a second time and a third time the senior venerable kept silent.

sn41.3:4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā isidatto tasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe sabbanavako hoti.
sn41.3:4.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Isidatta was the most junior mendicant in that Saṅgha.

sn41.3:4.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā isidatto āyasmantaṃ theraṃ etadavoca:
sn41.3:4.2.eng: He said to the venerable senior,

sn41.3:4.3.pli: “byākaromahaṃ, bhante thera, cittassa gahapatino etaṃ pañhan”ti?
sn41.3:4.3.eng: “Honorable Senior, may I answer Citta’s question?”

sn41.3:4.4.pli: “Byākarohi tvaṃ, āvuso isidatta, cittassa gahapatino etaṃ pañhan”ti.

sn41.3:4.6.pli: ‘yā imā, bhante thera, anekavihitā diṭṭhiyo loke uppajjanti—
sn41.3:4.6.eng: ‘There are many different views that arise in the world …

sn41.3:4.8.pli: imā nu kho, bhante, diṭṭhiyo kismiṃ sati honti, kismiṃ asati na hontī’”ti?
sn41.3:4.8.eng: When what exists do these views come to be? When what doesn’t exist do these views not come to be?’”

sn41.3:4.10.pli: “Yā imā, gahapati, anekavihitā diṭṭhiyo loke uppajjanti:
sn41.3:4.10.eng: “Householder, there are many different views that arise in the world. For example:

sn41.3:4.11.pli: ‘sassato lokoti vā, asassato lokoti vā, antavā lokoti vā anantavā lokoti vā, taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīranti vā, aññaṃ jīvaṃ aññaṃ sarīranti vā, hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā.
sn41.3:4.11.eng: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are one and the same, or the soul is one thing, the body another; after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.

sn41.3:4.12.pli: Yāni cimāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni brahmajāle bhaṇitāni;
sn41.3:4.12.eng: And also the sixty-two misconceptions spoken of in “The Divine Net”.

sn41.3:4.13.pli: imā kho, gahapati, diṭṭhiyo sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā sati honti, sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā asati na hontī’”ti.
sn41.3:4.13.eng: These views come to be when substantialist view exists. When substantialist view does not exist they do not come to be.”

sn41.3:5.1.eng: “But sir, how does substantialist view come about?”

sn41.3:5.2.pli: “Idha, gahapati, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
sn41.3:5.2.eng: “It’s when an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn41.3:5.3.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;
sn41.3:5.3.eng: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn41.3:5.7.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn41.3:5.7.eng: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

sn41.3:5.8.eng: That’s how substantialist view comes about.”

sn41.3:6.1.eng: “But sir, how does substantialist view not come about?”

sn41.3:6.2.pli: “Idha, gahapati, sutavā ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto sappurisānaṃ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto
sn41.3:6.2.eng: “It’s when a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.

sn41.3:6.3.pli: na rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, na rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, na attani vā rūpaṃ, na rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ;
sn41.3:6.3.eng: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

sn41.3:6.7.pli: na viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, na viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ, na attani vā viññāṇaṃ, na viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
sn41.3:6.7.eng: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

sn41.3:6.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, gahapati, sakkāyadiṭṭhi na hotī”ti.
sn41.3:6.8.eng: That’s how substantialist view does not come about.”

sn41.3:7.1.eng: “Sir, where has Master Isidatta come from?”

sn41.3:7.3.pli: “Atthi, bhante, avantiyā isidatto nāma kulaputto amhākaṃ adiṭṭhasahāyo pabbajito?
sn41.3:7.3.eng: “Sir, there’s a friend of mine named Isidatta who I’ve never met. He’s gone forth from a good family in Avanti.

sn41.3:7.6.pli: “Kahaṃ nu kho so, bhante, āyasmā etarahi viharatī”ti?
sn41.3:7.6.eng: “Sir, where is that venerable now staying?”

sn41.3:7.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā isidatto tuṇhī ahosi.
sn41.3:7.7.eng: When he said this, Isidatta kept silent.

sn41.3:7.10.eng: “Sir, I hope Master Isidatta is happy here in Macchikāsaṇḍa,

sn41.3:7.11.eng: for the Wild Mango Grove is lovely.

sn41.3:7.12.eng: I’ll make sure that Master Isidatta is provided with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.”

sn41.3:7.13.eng: “That’s nice of you to say, householder.”

sn41.3:8.1.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati āyasmato isidattassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā there bhikkhū paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
sn41.3:8.1.eng: Then Citta, having approved and agreed with what Isidatta said, served and satisfied the senior mendicants with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

sn41.3:8.2.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū bhuttāvino onītapattapāṇino uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃsu.
sn41.3:8.2.eng: When the senior mendicants had eaten and washed their hands and bowls, they got up from their seats and left.

sn41.3:8.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā thero āyasmantaṃ isidattaṃ etadavoca:
sn41.3:8.3.eng: Then the venerable senior said to Venerable Isidatta,

sn41.3:8.4.pli: “sādhu kho taṃ, āvuso isidatta, eso pañho paṭibhāsi.
sn41.3:8.4.eng: “Isidatta, it’s good that you felt inspired to answer that question, because I didn’t.

sn41.3:8.6.pli: Tenahāvuso isidatta, yadā aññathāpi evarūpo pañho āgaccheyya, taññevettha paṭibhāseyyā”ti.
sn41.3:8.6.eng: So when a similar question comes up, you should also answer it as you feel inspired.”

sn41.3:8.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmā isidatto senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya macchikāsaṇḍamhā pakkāmi.
sn41.3:8.7.eng: But Isidatta set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, left Macchikāsaṇḍa,

sn41.3:8.8.pli: Yaṃ macchikāsaṇḍamhā pakkāmi, tathā pakkantova ahosi, na puna paccāgacchīti.

sn41.4:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā therā bhikkhū macchikāsaṇḍe viharanti ambāṭakavane.
sn41.4:1.1.eng: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.

sn41.4:1.2.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati there bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn41.4:1.2.eng: Then Citta the householder went up to them, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to them,

sn41.4:1.3.pli: “adhivāsentu me, bhante, therā svātanāya gokule bhattan”ti.
sn41.4:1.3.eng: “Honorable Seniors, please accept my offering of tomorrow’s meal in my barn.”

sn41.4:1.5.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn41.4:1.5.eng: Then, knowing that the senior mendicants had consented, Citta got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled them, keeping them on his right, before leaving.

sn41.4:1.6.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena cittassa gahapatino gokulaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdiṃsu.
sn41.4:1.6.eng: Then when the night had passed, the senior mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, went to Citta’s barn, and sat down on the seats spread out.

sn41.4:2.1.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati there bhikkhū paṇītena sappipāyāsena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
sn41.4:2.1.eng: Then Citta served and satisfied the senior mendicants with his own hands with delicious milk-rice made with ghee.

sn41.4:2.2.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū bhuttāvino onītapattapāṇino uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃsu.
sn41.4:2.2.eng: When the senior mendicants had eaten and washed their hands and bowls, they got up from their seats and left.

sn41.4:2.3.pli: Cittopi kho gahapati “sesakaṃ vissajjethā”ti vatvā there bhikkhū piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi.
sn41.4:2.3.eng: Citta instructed that the leftovers of the food be distributed, then followed behind the senior mendicants.

sn41.4:2.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena uṇhaṃ hoti kuthitaṃ;
sn41.4:2.4.eng: Now at that time the heat was sweltering.

sn41.4:2.5.pli: te ca therā bhikkhū paveliyamānena maññe kāyena gacchanti, yathā taṃ bhojanaṃ bhuttāvino.
sn41.4:2.5.eng: And those senior mendicants walked along as if their bodies were melting, as happens after a meal.

sn41.4:3.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahako tasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe sabbanavako hoti.
sn41.4:3.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Mahaka was the most junior mendicant in that Saṅgha.

sn41.4:3.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahako āyasmantaṃ theraṃ etadavoca:
sn41.4:3.2.eng: Then Venerable Mahaka said to the senior venerable,

sn41.4:3.3.pli: “sādhu khvassa, bhante thera, sītako ca vāto vāyeyya, abbhasampilāpo ca assa, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyeyyā”ti.
sn41.4:3.3.eng: “Wouldn’t it be nice, Honorable Senior, if a cool wind blew, a cloud canopy formed, and a gentle rain drizzled down?”

sn41.4:4.1.pli: “Sādhu khvassa, āvuso mahaka, yaṃ sītako ca vāto vāyeyya, abbhasampilāpo ca assa, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyeyyā”ti.
sn41.4:4.1.eng: “It would indeed be nice, Reverend Mahaka.”

sn41.4:4.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahako tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhari yathā sītako ca vāto vāyi, abbhasampilāpo ca assa, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusi.
sn41.4:4.2.eng: Then Mahaka used his psychic power to will that a cool wind would blow, a cloud canopy would form, and a gentle rain would drizzle down.

sn41.4:4.4.pli: “yo kho imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe sabbanavako bhikkhu tassāyaṃ evarūpo iddhānubhāvo”ti.
sn41.4:4.4.eng: “The most junior mendicant in this Saṅgha has such psychic power!”

sn41.4:4.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahako ārāmaṃ sampāpuṇitvā āyasmantaṃ theraṃ etadavoca:
sn41.4:4.5.eng: When they reached the monastery, Mahaka said to the senior venerable,

sn41.4:4.10.pli: Atha kho therā bhikkhū yathāvihāraṃ agamaṃsu.
sn41.4:4.10.eng: Then the senior mendicants entered their dwellings,

sn41.4:4.11.eng: and Mahaka entered his own dwelling.

sn41.4:5.1.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yenāyasmā mahako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahakaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati āyasmantaṃ mahakaṃ etadavoca:
sn41.4:5.1.eng: Then Citta went up to Mahaka, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn41.4:5.2.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, ayyo mahako uttari manussadhammaṃ iddhipāṭihāriyaṃ dassetū”ti.
sn41.4:5.2.eng: “Sir, please show me a superhuman demonstration of psychic power.”

sn41.4:5.3.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, gahapati, ālinde uttarāsaṅgaṃ paññapetvā tiṇakalāpaṃ okāsehī”ti.
sn41.4:5.3.eng: “Well, then, householder, place your upper robe on the porch and spread a handful of grass on it.”

sn41.4:5.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho citto gahapati āyasmato mahakassa paṭissutvā ālinde uttarāsaṅgaṃ paññapetvā tiṇakalāpaṃ okāsesi.
sn41.4:5.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Citta, and did as he was asked.

sn41.4:5.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahako vihāraṃ pavisitvā sūcighaṭikaṃ datvā tathārūpaṃ iddhābhisaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkhari yathā tālacchiggaḷena ca aggaḷantarikāya ca acci nikkhamitvā tiṇāni jhāpesi, uttarāsaṅgaṃ na jhāpesi.
sn41.4:5.5.eng: Mahaka entered his dwelling and latched the door. Then he used his psychic power to will that a flame shoot out through the keyhole and the chink in the door-panel, and it burned up the grass but not the upper robe.

sn41.4:5.6.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati uttarāsaṅgaṃ papphoṭetvā saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn41.4:5.6.eng: Then Citta shook out his upper robe and stood to one side, shocked and awestruck.

sn41.4:5.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahako vihārā nikkhamitvā cittaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavoca:
sn41.4:5.7.eng: Mahaka left his dwelling and said to Citta,

sn41.4:6.4.eng: I hope Master Mahaka is happy here in Macchikāsaṇḍa,

sn41.4:6.5.eng: for the Wild Mango Grove is lovely.

sn41.4:6.6.eng: I’ll make sure that Master Mahaka is provided with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.”

sn41.4:6.7.eng: “That’s nice of you to say, householder.”

sn41.4:6.8.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahako senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya macchikāsaṇḍamhā pakkāmi.
sn41.4:6.8.eng: But Mahaka set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, left Macchikāsaṇḍa,

sn41.4:6.9.pli: Yaṃ macchikāsaṇḍamhā pakkāmi, tathā pakkantova ahosi;

sn41.5:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā kāmabhū macchikāsaṇḍe viharati ambāṭakavane.
sn41.5:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Kāmabhū was staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.

sn41.5:1.2.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yenāyasmā kāmabhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ kāmabhuṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho cittaṃ gahapatiṃ āyasmā kāmabhū etadavoca:
sn41.5:1.2.eng: Then Citta the householder went up to Venerable Kāmabhū, bowed, and sat down to one side. Kāmabhū said to him,

sn41.5:4.1.pli: Imassa nu kho, gahapati, saṅkhittena bhāsitassa kathaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
sn41.5:4.1.eng: How should we see the detailed meaning of this brief statement?”

sn41.5:4.2.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho etaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā bhāsitan”ti?
sn41.5:4.2.eng: “Sir, was this spoken by the Buddha?”

sn41.5:4.4.pli: “Tena hi, bhante, muhuttaṃ āgamehi yāvassa atthaṃ pekkhāmī”ti.
sn41.5:4.4.eng: “Well then, sir, please wait a while while I consider the meaning of this.”

sn41.5:4.5.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati muhuttaṃ tuṇhī hutvā āyasmantaṃ kāmabhuṃ etadavoca:
sn41.5:4.5.eng: Then after staying silent for a while, Citta said to Kāmabhū:

sn41.5:5.1.eng: “Sir, ‘flawless wheel’ is a term for ethics.

sn41.5:5.2.eng: ‘White canopy’ is a term for freedom.

sn41.5:5.3.eng: ‘One spoke’ is a term for mindfulness.

sn41.5:5.4.eng: ‘Rolls on’ is a term for going forward and coming back.

sn41.5:5.5.pli: ‘Ratho’ti kho, bhante, imassetaṃ cātumahābhūtikassa kāyassa adhivacanaṃ mātāpettikasambhavassa odanakummāsūpacayassa aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammassa.
sn41.5:5.5.eng: ‘Chariot’ is a term for this body made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.

sn41.5:5.6.pli: Rāgo kho, bhante, nīgho, doso nīgho, moho nīgho.
sn41.5:5.6.eng: Greed, hate, and delusion are troubles.

sn41.5:5.7.pli: Te khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn41.5:5.7.eng: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

sn41.5:5.8.eng: That’s why a mendicant who has ended the defilements is called ‘untroubled’.

sn41.5:5.9.eng: ‘The one who comes’ is a term for the perfected one.

sn41.5:5.11.pli: Sā khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn41.5:5.11.eng: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given this up, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, and obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.

sn41.5:5.12.eng: That’s why a mendicant who has ended the defilements is said to have ‘cut the stream’.

sn41.5:5.13.pli: Rāgo kho, bhante, bandhanaṃ, doso bandhanaṃ, moho bandhanaṃ.
sn41.5:5.13.eng: Greed, hate, and delusion are bonds.

sn41.5:5.14.pli: Te khīṇāsavassa bhikkhuno pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
sn41.5:5.14.eng: A mendicant who has ended the defilements has given these up, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, and obliterated them, so they are unable to arise in the future.

sn41.5:5.15.eng: That’s why a mendicant who has ended the defilements is called ‘unbound’.

sn41.5:5.16.pli: Iti kho, bhante, yaṃ taṃ bhagavatā vuttaṃ:
sn41.5:5.16.eng: So, sir, that’s how I understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha said in brief:

sn41.5:7.1.pli: Imassa kho, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.

sn41.5:7.3.pli: Yassa te gambhīre buddhavacane paññācakkhu kamatī”ti.
sn41.5:7.3.eng: to traverse the Buddha’s deep teachings with the eye of wisdom.”
